author: By Farah Stockman
title: Biden’s Pro-Labor Vision Goes Beyond America
description: The global rules of trade are being rewritten, and the Biden administration wants to make them more labor-friendly.
content: President Biden ran on a promise to be the most pro-labor president ever. A year into his presidency, it is becoming clear that he is already the most pro-labor president since Franklin Delano Roosevelt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Morgan Campbell
title: After the Verbal Sparring, Covington Dominates Masvidal on the Mat
description: The welterweight contenders, once friends, fought in a bout that was more about their personal vendettas than a path to a belt.
content: After a quick exchange of punches to open the final round of the main event at U.F.C. 272, the welterweight contender Colby Covington advanced on Jorge Masvidal, bulldozed him into the fence and dragged him to the canvas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: What We Know About Brittney Griner’s Detention in Russia
description: The W.N.B.A. star was stopped at an airport outside Moscow and accused of carrying hashish oil in her luggage. But much about the case remains unclear.
content: As tensions rose between Russia and the United States, Russian authorities detained Brittney Griner, a W.N.B.A. star, on drug charges. The Russian Federal Customs Service announced Ms. Griner’s detention on Saturday but said she was stopped at the Sheremetyevo airport near Moscow last month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Russian Prisoners and Ukrainian Soldiers Describe Two Sides of the Conflict
description: The accounts painted a picture of a conflict consisting largely of ambushes, at least in northern Ukraine where the Russian forces are striving to encircle and capture the capital, Kyiv.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — With hands still dirty from the battlefield, a dozen Russian prisoners of war sat, stony-faced, in a conference room of a Ukrainian news agency on Saturday and described being captured after their armored columns were ambushed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margot Sanger-Katz, Claire Cain Miller and Quoctrung Bui
title: Most Women Denied Abortions by Texas Law Got Them Another Way
description: New data suggests overall abortions declined much less than previously known, because women traveled out of state or ordered pills online.
content: In the months after Texas banned all but the earliest abortions in September, the number of legal abortions in the state fell by about half. But two new studies suggest the total number among Texas women fell by far less — around 10 percent — because of large increases in the number of Texans who traveled to a clinic in a nearby state or ordered abortion pills online.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Dennis Cunningham, Civil Rights Lawyer for Varied Causes, Dies at 86
description: He successfully represented the Black Panthers, environmentalists who accused the government of conspiracy and Attica prison inmates.
content: Dennis Cunningham, a civil rights lawyer who successfully sued the government on behalf of the Black Panthers, rebellious Attica prison inmates and fervid environmentalists who claimed they were victims of official misconduct, died on Saturday at his son’s home in Los Angeles. He was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jin Yu Young
title: South Korea reports high turnout in early voting, but apologizes to coronavirus patients for a lack of preparation.
description: South Korea is experiencing a sharp spike in coronavirus cases, its worst wave of the pandemic, but is allowing infected voters to cast a ballot in the country’s contentious presidential election.
content: South Korea’s National Election Commission released an apology on Sunday for poor planning during special early voting hours for coronavirus patients that resulted in unexpectedly long waits at polling sites and, according to local media reports, some patients fainting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: ‘Mockingbird’ Made Her a Child Star. Now She’s in the Broadway Tour.
description: Six decades after she played Scout in the film version of “To Kill a Mockingbird,” Mary Badham takes on the role of a neighbor in the play’s national tour.
content: Mary Badham describes herself as “just a retired old lady who likes to be in her garden and play with her grandkids.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oscar Lopez
title: Mexico Soccer Riot Leaves 26 Injured, Officials Say
description: Videos posted on social media showed violent clashes between fans in a stadium in the central city of Querétaro on Saturday.
content: MEXICO CITY — A soccer game in central Mexico descended into violent clashes between fans of the opposing teams on Saturday. The authorities said 26 people had been injured, three of them critically.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Boris Johnson
title: Boris Johnson: 6 Steps the West Must Take to Help Ukraine Right Now
description: What happens in Europe will have profound implications worldwide.
content: LONDON — Over the past week, in response to the gut-wrenching scenes in Ukraine, Western unity has been impressive and heartening. I know from my near-daily conversations with President Volodymyr Zelensky that this has provided Ukrainians with some comfort in their hour of need.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Violet Kupersmith
title: NoViolet Bulawayo Allegorizes the Aftermath of Robert Mugabe
description: In “Glory,” a dictatorial elderly horse is unseated from his rule over the fictional African nation of Jidada.
content: GLORY By NoViolet Bulawayo
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘I Tried to Pick Up My Pace, Hunching Forward Into the Wind’
description: A walk in the rain, a treasured program and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trevor Timm
title: My Wife Tracked Me, for Journalism
description: For a recent Times article, the reporter Kashmir Hill followed her husband’s every move using location trackers. She knew where he was at all times — what she didn’t learn, though, was what he was doing. Read about his experience, with some notes from Kashmir.
content: Kashmir Hill recently published an article in The Times in which she detailed how she digitally followed her husband’s movements for a month using GPS and other location trackers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: They Weren’t Wanted at the Paralympics. They’re Excelling Anyway.
description: After a dispute over whether they should be allowed to compete, the snowboarders Cécile Hernandez and Brenna Huckaby are putting in strong performances.
content: ZHANGJIAKOU, China — Until the moment Cécile Hernandez of France was handed an official racing bib and a time slot on Saturday, she still feared that race officials would forbid her to compete.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan
title: Accused Leader in Sarah Lawrence Cult Case Is Set to Stand Trial
description: For about 10 years, Lawrence V. Ray abused and extorted a group of his daughter’s classmates at the college, prosecutors say.
content: In 2010, Lawrence V. Ray walked out of a New Jersey prison and into the lives of a group of students at Sarah Lawrence College, a small school just north of New York City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: Cuomo Re-emerges and Blames ‘Cancel Culture’ for His Fall
description: Andrew Cuomo, the ex-governor of New York, said in a speech at a Black church that he wanted to “tell my truth.”
content: Former Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo emerged from his self-imposed exile on Sunday, using his first public appearance in more than six months to cast himself as a victim of “cancel culture” and to vow to reinsert himself in New York’s political discourse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Monday Briefing: Russian Forces Attack Evacuees
description: Plus China’s new economic plan and updates on an attack on a Pakistani mosque.
content: As Russian forces continued shelling Ukraine, at least three people — a mother and her children — were killed outside Kyiv as they tried to get to safety. For the second straight day, the authorities called off an evacuation from the besieged port city of Mariupol.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater and Chris Cameron
title: U.S. lawmakers say they are largely opposed to a no-fly zone over Ukraine.
description: Members of both parties said such a move would risk drawing the United States into a conflict with Russia, another nuclear power.
content: WASHINGTON — Members of Congress on Sunday emphasized what has become a widely held position on Capitol Hill: that the United States should respond to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine by banning Russian oil imports, but not by imposing a no-fly zone over the country that could draw nuclear powers into war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shauntel Lowe
title: Why Brittney Griner and Other W.N.B.A. Stars Play Overseas
description: Competing for international teams during the W.N.B.A.’s off-season is common for players. The chance to earn extra money is just one of the draws.
content: Brittney Griner, a center for the Phoenix Mercury, has been detained in Russia in connection with a drug investigation. She had been there playing for the professional basketball team UMMC Ekaterinburg during the W.N.B.A. off-season. The news of her detention on Saturday prompted questions about safety and politics but also about logistics — namely: Why was one of the W.N.B.A.’s best players competing in Russia anyway?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: After a Punishing Sprint, Yannick Nézet-Séguin Can Celebrate
description: The Met Opera and Philadelphia Orchestra conductor recently took a break because of exhaustion. Then he found himself in the middle of a performance marathon.
content: However busy your past two weeks were, Yannick Nézet-Séguin’s were probably busier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: Police arrest more than 3,000 people as protests grow across Russia.
description: An activist group that tracks protests found demonstrations in nearly 50 cities on Sunday.
content: Despite the threat of yearslong prison terms, thousands of Russians joined antiwar rallies across the country on Sunday in a striking show of the pent-up anger in Russian society about President Vladimir V. Putin’s invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: On ‘S.N.L.,’ Tucker Carlson and Laura Ingraham Make Amends
description: The episode, hosted by Oscar Isaac, spoofed the Fox News hosts and the former president in a “Ukrainian Invasion Celebration Spectacular.”
content: A comedy sketch that ended with former President Trump performing a fairly sincere rendition of “My Funny Valentine” was not nearly the most baroque moment of this weekend’s “Saturday Night Live,” which was hosted by Oscar Isaac. (That particular honor would go to a routine about singing meatballs, which we’ll get to shortly.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By German Lopez
title: Police and the Alternatives
description: Murders have spiked in the U.S., and experts say a mix of solutions works best.
content: Debates over crime reduction are often binary, pitting the police against alternative approaches.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays, Dana Rubinstein and Grace Ashford
title: Asian Americans Grapple With Tide of Attacks: ‘We Need Our Safety Back’
description: Younger Asian American leaders want to rely less on traditional policing solutions, while more traditional cultural and business groups favor them.
content: She was attacked as she swept up in front of her Queens home in November, beaten in the head with a rock so viciously that she was in a coma for weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grace Ashford
title: Ready to ‘undo damage,’ some N.Y.C. restaurants cheer the lifting of an indoor vaccine mandate.
description: Starting Monday the city will no longer require patrons in restaurants, bars and gyms and other places indoors to show proof of vaccination, part of a rollback that includes lifting the mask requirement in public schools.
content: No vaccine card?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina and Vimal Patel
title: Tornadoes Rampage Across Iowa, Killing 7, Officials Say
description: The National Weather Service said at least three tornadoes moved through the state on Saturday, including one with wind speeds of more than 135 miles per hour.
content: Seven people, including two children, were killed in Iowa on Saturday as communities across the state were battered by at least three tornadoes that destroyed dozens of homes, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: Matt Reeves Explains the Ending of ‘The Batman’
description: The film’s director and co-writer talks about the tumultuous conclusion and its chilling parallels to the real world. Read this after you’ve seen the movie.
content: This interview contains spoilers for the ending of “The Batman.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Morris and Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: High Demand for Drug to Prevent Covid in the Vulnerable, Yet Doses Go Unused
description: The treatment could be lifesaving for many who cannot get protection from the vaccine, but confusion about the drug has made some doctors slow to prescribe it.
content: Sasha Mallett, Sue Taylor and Kimberly Cooley all have immune deficiencies that make them especially vulnerable to Covid-19, and all have tried to get the same thing: a new treatment that can prevent the disease in people who either cannot produce antibodies after receiving a coronavirus vaccine or cannot get vaccinated at all.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: March 6, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, March 6, 2022.
content: An article on Feb. 20 about Sam Waterston and “Law & Order” misstated the location of the school where Waterston’s father taught. It was in northeast Massachusetts, not northwest Massachusetts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Waterman
title: How to View the Northern Lights From New England and the Midwest
description: With careful planning, timing and luck, witnessing the aurora borealis in the Lower 48 is one of the greatest yet most rarely seen spectacles for anyone willing to sacrifice a bit of sleep.
content: Several years ago, on a cold, mid-March evening at about 10 p.m., I took my dogs out for a walk beyond the lights of our home in Carbondale, Colo. The sky was ablaze with stars, and as I looked up for the Big Dipper and the North Star, I noticed that the far horizon pulsated in a green glow. I couldn’t believe that I was seeing the northern lights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: For German Firms, Ties to Russia Are Personal, Not Just Financial
description: The economic fallout from Russia’s invasion of Ukraine is only part of the pain for German companies.
content: BERLIN — When Peter Fenkl heard that Russia had invaded Ukraine, he said his first thoughts were not for the business his German company stood to lose in either country, but for the fates of his employees in the region, who over years of business dealings and shared drinks had become more than just colleagues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval and Reid J. Epstein
title: Indicted. Under F.B.I. Investigation. And Still Popular With Texas Republicans.
description: Ken Paxton, the Texas attorney general, earned the most votes in Tuesday’s G.O.P. primary. His embrace of Trumpism has helped him weather a series of allegations.
content: SAN ANTONIO — The race for Texas attorney general is asking Republicans to determine how many indictments and allegations of corruption are too many. The answer may be there is no limit — so long as the candidate has an endorsement from former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: After Zelensky’s Plea, the West Raced to Form a United Front
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, March 6, 2022.
content: “They do not keep up with new threats. They are not effective for overcoming them. This is a cough syrup when you need a coronavirus vaccine.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley and Lananh Nguyen
title: Fraud Is Flourishing on Zelle. The Banks Say It’s Not Their Problem.
description: Zelle, the payments platform used by millions of customers, is a popular target of scammers. But banks have been reluctant to make fraud victims whole — despite owning the system.
content: Justin Faunce lost $500 to a scammer impersonating a Wells Fargo official in January and hoped that the bank would reimburse him. Mr. Faunce was a longtime Wells Fargo customer and had immediately reported the scam — involving Zelle, the popular money transfer app.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger and Lara Jakes
title: U.S. is exploring how to send Soviet-era fighter jets to Ukraine.
description: The discussions follow President Volodymyr Zelensky’s impassioned plea to American legislators for assistance in obtaining more lethal military aid.
content: The Biden administration is discussing how to supply Polish Soviet-era fighter jets to Ukraine, American officials say, after President Volodymyr Zelensky made a passionate plea to American legislators on Saturday for assistance in obtaining more lethal military aid, especially Russian-made jets that Ukrainian pilots know how to fly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kessler
title: The Week in Business: Guns vs. Economic Sanctions
description: U.S. employers added 678,000 jobs in February, a strong gain. President Biden unveiled a new coronavirus defense strategy. And we’re about to hear how much prices rose in February.
content: More than one million people have fled Ukraine since Russian troops moved in. Much of the response from Western countries has been economic. The United States, the European Union, Britain and other nations agreed to remove Russia from the SWIFT financial messaging system, essentially barring the country from international transactions, and impose restrictions on its central bank. The sanctions seem to have had an immediate effect on Russia’s financial situation: The ruble crashed, Russia’s stock market froze and Russians rushed to withdraw cash. Businesses also took aim at Russia’s economy. Oil companies said they would exit investments in Russia; H&M and Apple paused sales in the country; and Disney and Warner Bros. said they’d pause theatrical movie releases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Monika Pronczuk
title: ‘Falling Into Emptiness’: Ukrainian Families Feel the Pain of Separation
description: With most Ukrainian men legally prohibited from leaving Ukraine, the international border gates serve as a painful filter, splitting families as women and children move on.
content: MEDYKA, Poland — Iryna Dukhota has been married to her husband for 26 years. She met him when they were young, as he was riding his bike through her neighborhood in Kyiv, Ukraine’s capital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheera Frenkel
title: TikTok suspends livestreaming and new uploads from Russia.
description: Millions of people have turned to TikTok for live updates from Ukraine.
content: TikTok said on Sunday that it would suspend livestreaming and new content being uploaded from Russia, becoming the latest tech company to pull back from the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: ‘The Batman’ Opens With Blockbuster Ticket Sales
description: The movie took in nearly $250 million worldwide. In some domestic theaters, it was about $1 more for standard “Batman” tickets than for other movies.
content: “The Batman” took in a blockbuster $128.5 million at theaters in the United States and Canada over the weekend, demonstrating the staying power of one of Hollywood’s most overworked superheroes and marking an end — cinema owners hope — to studio experimentation with movie release patterns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Tamisiea
title: Fossil Reveals Secrets of One of Nature’s Most Mysterious Reptiles
description: The specimen shows that modern tuataras found in New Zealand are little changed from ancestors that lived 190 million years ago.
content: New Zealand’s tuataras look like somber iguanas. But these spiny reptiles are not actually lizards. Instead, they are the last remnant of a mysterious and ancient order of reptiles known as the Rhynchocephalians that mostly vanished after their heyday in the Jurassic period.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: On Ukraine’s Border, Moldovans Wonder: Where Will Putin Stop?
description: Moldovans fear that Transnistria, a region run by Russia-backed separatists in eastern Moldova, might be the next target after Ukraine.
content: ON THE DNIESTER RIVER — Just eight miles from the Ukrainian border, the mayor of a village in Moldova watched rolling television coverage of the Russian invasion next door. He fiddled with a pen, removing and replacing its lid, staring at the screen as it showed the Russian advance toward Odessa, the nearest big city on the Ukrainian side.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $1 Million
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Things Learned in Kindergarten
description: Sam Acker gets even.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — Happy Monday, folks! And congratulations to Sam Acker, who is making his New York Times Crossword debut today (that’s debut No. 18 on the year, for those of you keeping score at home).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Pressed About Putin, Russian Conductor Quits Bolshoi and French Posts
description: The Bolshoi music director, Tugan Sokhiev, said he was “asked to choose one cultural tradition” over another and denounce President Putin for invading Ukraine.
content: A prominent Russian conductor said on Sunday that he would resign from his positions with two orchestras — at the storied Bolshoi Theater in Moscow and in Toulouse, France — after facing intense pressure to condemn President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsey Addario
title: Russian forces fire on evacuees, leaving 4 people dead outside Kyiv.
description: The attack in Irpin, west of the capital, suggested either direct targeting of evacuees or disregard for the risk of civilian casualties.
content: IRPIN, Ukraine — A Russian force advancing on Kyiv fired mortar shells on Sunday at a battered bridge used by evacuees fleeing the fighting, sending panicked civilians running and leaving four people dead on the pavement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Demanding That Ketanji Brown Jackson ‘Show Her Papers’
description: Too many Black people have had to present proof of their credentials at some point in their lives. It is humiliating and degrading.
content: The Fox News host Tucker Carlson briefly went to a Swiss boarding school before reportedly being kicked out. He went on to graduate from Trinity College. In a 1991 yearbook entry, he described himself as being part of the “Dan White Society,” an apparent allusion to the homophobe who killed San Francisco’s mayor, George Moscone, and supervisor Harvey Milk, California’s first openly gay elected official, in 1978.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: Review: A Ballerina With Jazz in Her Bones Takes Over
description: Tiler Peck, a principal dancer at New York City Ballet, directs her own evening as part of City Center’s inaugural Artists at the Center series.
content: An exceptionally musical dancer, Tiler Peck has an ear for rhythm. But as a director and curator, she also has an eye — for talent, for selecting equally eager, go-for-broke collaborators and for exploring, in disparate ways, the visualization of sound.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Binelli, Jack D'Isidoro, Aaron Esposito, John Woo, Elisheba Ittoop and Zachary Mouton
title: The Sunday Read: ‘The Waco Biker Shootout Left Nine Dead. Why Was No One Convicted?’
description: How 177 arrests led to no convictions — a tangled, seven-year tale of prosecutorial hubris and tenacious defense.
content: It was a perplexing event, with little in the way of legal closure. Seven years on from a fatal biker shootout in 2015, Mark Binelli explores the details of the event — which started as a brawl between rival “outlaw” motorcycle clubs, the Cossacks and the Bandidos, at a restaurant in Waco, West Texas, which left nine dead and 20 wounded — and the investigation that followed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg
title: Q. & A.: How to Deal With Running Injuries
description: How can you avoid overuse injuries? Can you run through upper body pain? What kind of cross-training is the most efficient? Your injury questions, answered.
content: The world’s greatest runners speak poetically about how they deal with physical pain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder and Al Drago
title: A Thunderous Farewell at Duke for Coach K, Even in Defeat
description: Mike Krzyzewski walked Cameron Indoor Stadium’s sideline for the last time as Duke’s maestro. There was also a basketball game, which Duke lost.
content: DURHAM, N.C. — Before we get to the score, you should — no, you must — know what it was like at Cameron Indoor Stadium on Saturday evening. That is the only way to appreciate what happened.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: In Burundi, the Drum Is a Revered Symbol of Unity. But Only Men Can Play.
description: Burundian drumming is a global phenomenon, featured in blockbuster movies and best-selling albums. But at home, authorities have restricted it to official functions — and banned women from performing.
content: GITEGA, Burundi — An ensemble of about 30 men, balancing heavy instruments on their heads, walked in a solemn procession to a red-soil field, where the silence would soon be replaced by a sound essential to the cultural identity of Burundi: drumming.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madeleine Ngo, Adam Bednar and Esha Ray
title: Led by Truckers, Hundreds of Vehicles Protesting Covid Mandates Encircle Washington
description: The convoy slowed traffic outside the capital for hours before fading in the afternoon.
content: WASHINGTON — Draped in American flags and fueled by anger, hundreds of vehicles led by a group of truckers encircled the nation’s capital on Sunday, hampering traffic outside the city for hours by driving at slower speeds to protest Covid-19 mandates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mary Tuma
title: Texas Is the Future of Abortion in America
description: What happens in the state rarely stays there.
content: For half a year, Roe v. Wade — the 1973 Supreme Court decision that guarantees abortion rights for all Americans — has been effectively moot in the second largest state in the country, home to about 10 percent of the nation’s reproductive-age women.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Yaffe-Bellany
title: Gas Prices in U.S. Climb Above $4 a Gallon
description: The national average price on Sunday was $4.009 a gallon, approaching a record set in 2008.
content: Gas prices in the United States are climbing to their highest level since 2008, as Russia’s invasion of Ukraine disrupts the global energy market.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tish Harrison Warren
title: We’re All Sinners, and Accepting That Is Actually a Good Thing
description: A realistic understanding of sin makes forgiveness and grace possible.
content: This is the first Sunday of Lent, a season in preparation for Easter when Christians often focus on sin and repentance. One of the things that’s most difficult to swallow about Christianity is the idea that normal, nice people are sinners, that we are born sinful and can’t elude being a sinner by being moral or religious enough.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: The Gangs of Fashion
description: Marine Serre spawns an almost-riot. Loewe gets surrealist. Allegiances are being declared.
content: PARIS — It was 9:30 p.m. on a Friday and the crowd in the Fourth Arrondissement was a pulsating mass of bodies, crushed together and shoving forward, on the edge of out of control. Security guards were yelling and trying to shut a pair of ornate iron gates to limit entry, and guests desperate to get in were yelling right back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esha Ray
title: Truckers protesting Covid mandates are amassing outside the capital.
description: The convoy and its supporters could move into Washington to hold rallies.
content: One group of truckers called the People’s Convoy that left California more than a week ago made it to the East Coast and was stationed on Saturday in Hagerstown, Md., about 70 miles northwest of the capital, converging with other drivers and their supporters — opening up the possibility that the convoy could move into Washington to hold protests against pandemic restrictions in the next few days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Walter R. Mears, ‘Boys on the Bus’ Campaign Reporter, Dies at 87
description: He won a Pulitzer while reporting on politics for The Associated Press, and in an enduring 1973 book he epitomized the virtues of wire service journalism.
content: Walter R. Mears, a longtime reporter at The Associated Press whose on-the-spot analyses of American politics won him a Pulitzer Prize and a role in “The Boys on the Bus,” an enduring 1973 book about presidential campaign correspondents, died on Thursday at his home in Chapel Hill, N.C. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: The Cancellation of Mother Russia Is Underway
description: China is the one country that might have the power to stop Putin.
content: With every passing day, the war in Ukraine becomes a bigger tragedy for the Ukrainian people but also a bigger threat to the future of Europe and the world at large. There is only one country that might have the power to stop it now, and it’s not the United States. It’s China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora and Andrew E. Kramer
title: Here is the latest news about Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
description: LVIV, Ukraine — After Western nations rejected his appeal to impose a no-fly zone over the country, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine on Sunday called on the entire nation to resist the Russian invasion. He cheered the courage of protesters who filled the streets of occupied cities and towns, saying that “every meter of our Ukrainian land won by protest and humiliation of the invaders is a step forward, a step toward victory.”
content: LVIV, Ukraine — After Western nations rejected his appeal to impose a no-fly zone over the country, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine on Sunday called on the entire nation to resist the Russian invasion. He cheered the courage of protesters who filled the streets of occupied cities and towns, saying that “every meter of our Ukrainian land won by protest and humiliation of the invaders is a step forward, a step toward victory.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsey Addario and Andrew E. Kramer
title: Ukrainian Family’s Dash for Safety Ends in Death
description: Russian forces hit a bridge being used by civilians evacuating the fighting in Ukraine. Four people were killed.
content: IRPIN, Ukraine — The bridge was just a shell of its old self, blown up days earlier by Ukrainian soldiers intent on slowing the Russian advance on the capital, Kyiv, but battered as it was, it offered a lifeline to civilians desperate to flee the fighting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zia ur-Rehman
title: As Women’s Marches Gain Steam in Pakistan, Conservatives Grow Alarmed
description: What began in 2018 as a single march for International Women’s Day has become an annual event in multiple cities. Opposition is rising, and threats are, too.
content: KARACHI, Pakistan — The reaction to Pakistan’s first women’s march was relatively mild: criticism and condemnation from Islamist parties and conservatives, who called the participants “anti-religion” and “vulgar.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins
title: Ukrainians Find That Relatives in Russia Don’t Believe It’s a War
description: Many Ukrainians are encountering a confounding and frustrating backlash from family members in Russia who have bought into the official Kremlin messaging.
content: LVIV, Ukraine — Four days after Russia began dropping artillery shells on Kyiv, Misha Katsiurin, a Ukrainian restaurateur, was wondering why his father, a church custodian living in the Russian city of Nizhny Novgorod, hadn’t called to check on him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsey Addario
title: In photos: Evacuation comes under fire near Kyiv.
description: Russian forces shelled Irpin, west of Kyiv, as civilians attempted to flee to safety on Sunday. At least three people were killed.
content: Russian forces shelled Irpin, west of Kyiv, as civilians attempted to flee to safety on Sunday. At least three people were killed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: What Is NATO and Which Countries Are Members?
description: This Western mutual-defense alliance, which sees an attack on one member as an attack on all, is central to the war in Ukraine, even though Ukraine is not a member.
content: Though Ukraine has been pressing for years to become a member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, or NATO, it hasn’t been granted membership. Still the 73-year-old defense alliance’s eastward-growing footprint is among the reasons President Vladimir V. Putin has cited for invading Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Ramzy
title: Here’s why Western leaders are reluctant to impose a no-fly zone over Ukraine.
description: Enforcing a ban on aircraft could draw more countries into conflict against Russia and set off “a full-fledged war in Europe,” NATO’s leader has warned.
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky and others have called for NATO to impose a no-fly zone over Ukraine to counter the threat from Russian military aircraft. For now, NATO leaders have said they aren’t willing, fearful such a move could drag them into a broader war with Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: In Derby Without Drama, City Wins a Laugher
description: The Manchester derby has changed, mostly because United can no longer keep pace and City no longer has anything to prove.
content: MANCHESTER, England — There was no tension in the last few minutes. It had gone long before the fourth goal arrived, marking the point at which victory turned into a rout. So had what little anxiety, what scant fretfulness might still have lingered. Instead, in the final few minutes of a derby, Manchester City’s fans could let go and enjoy themselves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | March 7, 2022
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.

author: By Elisa Gabbert
title: A Poem (and a Painting) About the Suffering That Hides in Plain Sight
description: With war looming, W.H. Auden stood in a museum and was inspired to write. The resulting poem, “Musée des Beaux Arts,” is one of the most famous ever written about art.
content: With war looming, W.H. Auden stood in a museum and was inspired to write. The resulting poem, “Musée des Beaux Arts,” is one of the most famous ever written about art.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Pets Have Put On Pandemic Weight, Too
description: Humans weren't the only ones who gained weight during lockdown.
content: Humans weren't the only ones who gained weight during lockdown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: Tornadoes in Iowa Leave at Least 7 Dead
description: Officials said that two children were among those killed and several other adults were injured, as communities across Iowa were battered by tornadoes.
content: Officials said that two children were among those killed and several other adults were injured, as communities across Iowa were battered by tornadoes.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Your Librarian Wants to Challenge, Not Ban
description: The president of the American Library Association and others respond to an essay claiming that “woke librarians” have an agenda. Also: “Acts of loving service.”
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Head into the week with new recipes from Ali Slagle, as well as a few old favorites.
content: Good morning. It’s been one of those weeks where all I’d like to do is to push off from a dock in Everglades City and slide into the Florida backcountry, maybe find some laid-up tarpon or snook but no people, no businesses, no phone service, no pinging news alerts, no existential dread. It’d be good to get a little lost. I could use the beauty and the adrenaline, the adventure and the escape.
source.name: The New York Times
